title: Paw Patrol: How to Find and Remove Ticks
author: Camille Noe Pagán

content: Ticks might be small bugs, but they can cause big problems for your dog.

Check your pet for ticks every day if they have been in a grassy or wooded area, no matter where you live. While these pests are more common in certain parts of the country, like the Northeast, they lurk in every state in the continental U.S.

Ticks feed on blood. When one of them bites your dog, it can pass on illnesses like Lyme disease and Rocky Mountain spotted fever . Both of these can cause stiffness , joint pain , and other health problems.

It takes a tick anywhere from 3 to up to 48 hours of feeding to infect an animal. But if you know how to find and remove them early, you can lower the chances of your dog getting sick. You can also make sure they don’t bring one of these pests into your home, where it could attach itself to you and make you ill.

content_blocks.text: Ticks might be small bugs, but they can cause big problems for your dog.

Check your pet for ticks every day if they have been in a grassy or wooded area, no matter where you live. While these pests are more common in certain parts of the country, like the Northeast, they lurk in every state in the continental U.S.

Ticks feed on blood. When one of them bites your dog, it can pass on illnesses like Lyme disease and Rocky Mountain spotted fever . Both of these can cause stiffness , joint pain , and other health problems.

It takes a tick anywhere from 3 to up to 48 hours of feeding to infect an animal. But if you know how to find and remove them early, you can lower the chances of your dog getting sick. You can also make sure they don’t bring one of these pests into your home, where it could attach itself to you and make you ill.

sections.heading: How to Check Your Dog for Ticks
content: 1. Give them a once-over before you go inside, or just inside the door, to lower the chance that a tick will get into your home.

2. Comb through their fur with your fingers. Press gently so you can feel any bumps on the skin . Ticks can be as small as a pinhead or as big as a grape. Don’t forget to check their feet (including between their toes ), inside their ears, and around the face and neck.
3. If you find a bump, part your dog’s fur so you can see their skin. Look for a black, brown, or grayish-brown bug. You might only see the tick’s body, or you might see its legs, too.
Checking for ticks on your dog

content_blocks.text: 1. Give them a once-over before you go inside, or just inside the door, to lower the chance that a tick will get into your home.

2. Comb through their fur with your fingers. Press gently so you can feel any bumps on the skin . Ticks can be as small as a pinhead or as big as a grape. Don’t forget to check their feet (including between their toes ), inside their ears, and around the face and neck.
3. If you find a bump, part your dog’s fur so you can see their skin. Look for a black, brown, or grayish-brown bug. You might only see the tick’s body, or you might see its legs, too.
Checking for ticks on your dog

sections.heading: How to Remove One
content: 1. You’ll need a pair of latex or rubber gloves, rubbing alcohol , an antibiotic ointment or antiseptic liquid, and a clean pair of tweezers or a tick-removing tool, which you can buy at pet supply stores.
2. Put your gloves on. Find the bug again and part your pooch’s fur so their skin and the tick are exposed.

2. Put your gloves on. Find the bug again and part your pooch’s fur so their skin and the tick are exposed.

sections.heading: How to Remove One
content: 1. You’ll need a pair of latex or rubber gloves, rubbing alcohol , an antibiotic ointment or antiseptic liquid, and a clean pair of tweezers or a tick-removing tool, which you can buy at pet supply stores.
2. Put your gloves on. Find the bug again and part your pooch’s fur so their skin and the tick are exposed.

content_blocks.text: 1. You’ll need a pair of latex or rubber gloves, rubbing alcohol , an antibiotic ointment or antiseptic liquid, and a clean pair of tweezers or a tick-removing tool, which you can buy at pet supply stores.
2. Put your gloves on. Find the bug again and part your pooch’s fur so their skin and the tick are exposed.

content: 3. If you’re using tweezers, grab the tick as close to your dog’s skin as you can and pull upward. Try to remove it in one motion. Jerking can cause part of the body to break off and get stuck in your pet’s skin.
If you have a tick removal tool, follow package instructions for removing a tick.

4. Put the tick in a glass jar, plastic bag, or something else you can seal shut. Add a teaspoon of rubbing alcohol. The alcohol will kill the bug. Save the container for a few weeks. If your dog seems ill, take the tick to your vet. They’ll examine it to see what kind it is, which can help them figure out if it made your pet ill.
5. Clean the bite and the skin around it with antiseptic, or dab it with antibiotic ointment. Clean the tweezers or tool with alcohol, and wash your hands, too.

6. Check the bite area often over the next few weeks. Call your vet if it looks irritated or infected. If your dog seems especially tired , has trouble walking, or doesn’t eat or drink as usual, make an appointment with your vet and take the tick with you.

sections.heading: If You Aren’t Sure You Can Remove a Tick
content: Call your vet. You can take your dog in, and they or a vet tech will remove it for you. Plus they can show you how, so you can take off the next one yourself.

sources: CDC: “Ticks: Geographic Distribution,” “Preventing Ticks On Your Pets,” “Tick Removal.”
American Kennel Club Canine Health Foundation: “Canine Tick-Borne Disease.”
University of Rhode Island TickEncounter Resource Center: “Protect Your Pets.”
The Humane Society of the United States: “Getting a Tick off Your Dog.”
meta_description: Don’t let the bad bugs bite! Learn how to check your dog for ticks -- and how to get rid of them when you find them.
